intro: Hygrophila helodes var. multiflora, commonly known as the water hygrophila, is a species of flowering plant in the family Acanthaceae. It is native to tropical regions of Asia and is often found in slow-moving freshwater environments such as ponds and marshes. The plant is characterized by its dense, branching stems and clusters of small, tubular flowers that are typically greenish-white in color. It is widely cultivated as an ornamental plant in aquariums and ponds due to its aesthetic appeal and ability to thrive in aquatic conditions. Additionally, it plays a role in water filtration and provides habitat for various aquatic organisms.
